p.seg: As for the wise men, who address themselves to the task of governing the world,
they must certainly know where the disorder arises from,
then they are able to govern it.
then they are not able to govern it.
Things are the same as with a doctor who wants to cure someone else's disease.
He must certainly know where the disease arises from,
then he is able to cure it.
If he does not know where the disease arises from,
then he is not able to cure it.
How, then, should it be any different for those who govern disorder?
They must certainly know where the disorder arises from,
then they are able to govern it.
If they do not know where the disorder arises from,
then they are not able to govern it.

As for the wise men, who address themselves to the task of governing the world,
they inevitably have to investigate where the disorder arises from.
Let us try to investigate where the disorder arises from.
It arises from the fact that people do not spare each other.
is something called disorder.
That subject and son do not serve their ruler or father in piety
Since a son spares himself and not his father,
he therefore harms his father and benefits himself.
Since a younger brother spares himself and not his older brother,
he therefore harms his older brother and benefits himself.
Since a subject spares himself and not his ruler,
he therefore harms his ruler and benefits himself.
This is something that is called disorder.
Even if the father does not show parental care for his son,
the elder brother does not show parental care for his younger brother,
the ruler does not show parental care for his subject,
then this is also something that the world calls disorder.
Since the father [actually] spares himself
and not his son,
he therefore harms his son and benefits himself.
Since the elder brother [actually] spares himself
and not his younger brother,
he therefore harms his younger brother and benefits himself.
Since the ruler [actually] spares himself
and not his subject,
he therefore harms his subject and benefits himself.
Why is this the case?
All this is due to the fact that people do not spare each other.
Even with those who are acting as robbers and murderers in the world,
it is the same.
A robber spares his [own] house,
but not others' houses,
therefore he robs others' houses in order to benefit his [own] house.
A murderer spares his [own] body,
but not [that of] others,
therefore he murders others in order to benefit his own.
Why is this the case?
All this is due to the fact that people do not spare each other.
Even with the great ones who bring their families into disorder mutually or with the rulers who attack their countries mutually,
it is the same.
The great ones each spare their own families,
but not other families,
therefore they bring other families into disorder in order to benefit their own families.
The rulers each spare their own countries,
but not foreign countries,
therefore they attack foreign countries in order to benefit their own countries.
All cases of disorder in the world
can be subsumed into this.
Let us investigate where this arises from.
All this is due to the fact that people do not spare each other.
If one made everyone in the world spare each other
and spare others as they spare their [own] bodies,
would there still be those who would not practice filial piety?
If one regarded one's father, older brother, and ruler like one's own body, how could one not [yet] practice filial piety?
Would there still be those who would not practice parental care?
If one regarded one's son, younger brother, and subject like one's own body,
how could one not [yet] practice parental care?
[for 有亡 read 亡有] Therefore, there would be no more lack of filial piety and parental care.
Would there still be robbers and murderers?
If one regarded other people's houses like one's own,
who would still rob other people's houses?
If one regarded other people's bodies like one's own,
who would still murder [other people]?
[for 有亡 read 亡有] Therefore, there would be no more robbers and murderers.
Would there still be great ones who would bring each other's families into disorder and rulers who would attack each other's countries?
If one regarded other people's families like one's own,
who would still cause disorder?
If one regarded the countries of others like one's [own] country,
who would still attack the countries of others?
[for 有亡 read 亡有] Therefore, there would be no more great ones who would bring each other's families into disorder and no more rulers who would attack each other's countries.
If one made everyone in the world spare each other,
countries would no longer attack each other,
families would no longer bring each other into disorder.
Robbers and murderers would no longer exist,
ruler and subject, father and son, would all be able to exercise filial piety and parental care.
If this was the case, the world would be in order.
Therefore, as for the wise men, who address themselves to the task of governing the world,
how can they not prohibit doing harm and encourage sparing?
If, therefore, everyone in the world spared each other, then order would prevail.
But if everyone harms each other, then disorder will reign.
Therefore, this is exactly what Master Mo [means when he] says
that one can't help but encourage others to spare themselves.

Master Mo says:
As for the way the humane man performs his tasks,
he must increase the benefits of the world
and avert the harm from the world.
This is the way he performs his tasks.
If this is so, what is the benefit of the world
and what is the harm of the world?
Master Mo says:
Well, when countries attack each other,
families rob each other,
people murder each other,
rulers are not benevolent and subjects are not loyal,
fathers do not exercise parental care and sons do not exercise filial piety,
and there is no harmony between older and younger brothers,
then this is the harm of the world.
If this is so, then let us investigate where this harm arises from!
Does it arise from sparing each other attentively?
Master Mo says:
It arises from not sparing each other attentively.
Well, the feudal lords merely know to spare their own countries attentively,
but not the countries of others,
so they do not fear to mobilize their own countries to attack the countries of others;
Well, the heads of families merely know to spare their own families,
but not the families of others,
so they do not fear to mobilize their own families to rob the families of others.
Well, people merely know to spare their own bodies attentively,
[but] not the bodies of others,
so they do not fear to use their own bodies to murder other people.
Therefore, if feudal lords do not spare each other attentively,
then it will certainly lead to open field battles.
If the heads of families do not spare each other attentively,
then it will certainly lead to them robbing each other.
If people do not spare each other attentively,
then it will certainly lead to them murdering each other.
If rulers and subjects do not spare each other attentively,
then rulers are not benevolent and subjects are not loyal.
If fathers and sons do not spare each other attentively,
then the former do not show parental care and the later do not show filial piety.
If older and younger brothers do not spare each other attentively,
then there is no harmony between them.
If the people of the world do not spare each other attentively,
the strong will certainly oppress the weak,
the majority will certainly subjugate the minority,
the rich will certainly demean the poor,
the noble will certainly disrespect the mean,
and the cunning will certainly deceive the stupid.
Speaking in principle of mischief, robbery, resentment and hatred,
what they arise from
is that one does not spare each other attentively.
Therefore the humane man condemns it decisively.
Since he already condemns it,
how does he change it?
Master Mo says:
With the method of universally sparing each other attentively and exchanging mutual benefits, he changes it.
If this is the case, what is the method of universally sparing each other attentively and exchanging mutual benefits?
Master Mo says:
Regard another's country
the way you regard your own country.
Regard another's household
the way you regard your own household.
Regard another's body
the way you regard your own body.
Therefore, if the feudal lords spare each other attentively,
then they do not fight open field battles.
If the heads of the households spare each other attentively,
then they do not rob each other.
If people spare each other attentively,
then they do not murder each other.
If the rulers and subjects spare each other attentively, then the former are benevolent and the latter loyal.
If fathers and sons spare each other attentively, then the former show parental care and the latter filial piety.
When older and younger brothers spare each other attentively, then there is harmony between them.
If all people in the world spare each other attentively,
then the strong do not oppress the weak,
the majority do not subjugate the minority,
the rich do not demean the poor,
the noble do not disrespect the poor,
the cunning do not deceive the stupid.
In principle, what is capable of preventing the emergence of disaster, robbery, resentment and hatred in the world
arises from sparing each other attentively.
Therefore the humane man praises it.
Although it is so, nowadays all the officials
and nobles in the world say:
That well may be.
So if there was universality, it would be good.
Although this is the case,
universality is a difficult thing to achieve in the world.
Master Mo says:
The officials and nobles in the world,
they alone do not realize its benefit and do not recognize its reason.
As for the siege of cities, waging open field battles,
and murdering to make a name for oneself,
this is what all the people in the world suffer from.
If the ruler takes pleasure in it,
then the officials and masses are capable of it.
But as far as the universal, reciprocal sparing of each other attentively and the exchange of mutual benefit are concerned,
these differ from this.
As for those who spare others attentively,
it is certain that the others will follow their example and spare them.
As for those who benefit others,
it is certain that the others will follow their example and benefit them.
As for those who harm others,
it is certain that the others will follow their example and harm them.
As for those who hurt others,
it is certain that the others will follow their example and hurt them.
What is so difficult about that?
The mere fact that the ruler refuses to make it a principle of government
is the reason why the officials do not make it a practice.
In former times, Jin Wengong liked the coarse clothing of the officials,
so Wengong's subjects
all wore coats of sheep's wool,
wrapped their swords in leather,
wore caps made of coarse silk
and garments made of coarse fabric,
and shoes made of hemp - this is how they stepped in to see the ruler
and stepped out to walk to court.
What was the reason for this?
The ruler had taken pleasure in it,
so the subjects were able to practice it.
In former times, Chu Lingwang liked it when the officials had a slim waist,
so Lingwang's subjects
all limited themselves to one meal a day.
They held their breath to gird themselves
and supported themselves against the wall to stand up.
After one year,
the faces of the court officials had become deeply grey.
What was the reason for this?
The ruler had taken pleasure in it,
so the subjects were able to practice it.
In former times, King Goujian of Yue liked it when his officials were brave.
He instructed his subjects, created unity between them and swore them to a common goal.
He had the ships set on fire and laid fire to them.
He put his officials to the test and said:
The treasures of the land of Yue are all in there!
The King of Yue drummed up his officials by himself and urged them forward.
When his officials heard the beat of the drum,
they set themselves in motion in great confusion. The number of those who perished in the fire
was over 100 followers.
The King of Yue had the bell to retreat sounded.
Therefore Master Mo says:
So as far as little eating, bad clothing and even suicide to make a name for oneself are concerned,
this is what the people of the world all suffer from.
If the ruler takes pleasure in it,
then the masses are capable of it.
However, as far as the universal, reciprocal sparing of each other and the exchange of mutual benefit are concerned, these differ from this.
As for those who spare others,
it is certain that others will also follow their example and spare them.
As for those who benefit others,
it is certain that others will also follow their example and benefit them.
As for those who harm others,
it is certain that others will also follow their example and harm them.
As for those who hurt others,
it is certain that others will also follow their example and hurt them.
What is so difficult about that?
The mere fact that the ruler refuses to make it a principle of government
is the reason why the officials do not make it a practice.
Although it is so, nowadays all the officials and nobles in the world say:
That well may be.
So if there would be universality, it would be good.
Although this is the case,
[universality] is an impossible thing to achieve.
It would be like trying to lift up Mount Tai and jump over the Yellow River and the Ji.
Master Mo says:
This is not an appropriate comparison.
As for lifting up Mount Tai and jumping over the Yellow River and the Ji,
it can be said that it requires supernatural strength.
From antiquity to the present day,
there has never been anyone who has been able to do so.
But as far as the universal, reciprocal sparing of each other and the exchange of mutual benefit are concerned, these differ from this.
The sage kings of ancient times practiced it.
How do you know this is so?
In ancient times, when Yu governed the world,
he built the Xihe and Yudou waterways in the west
to drain the Qu, Sun and Huang rivers.
In the north he created the Fang, Yuan and Gu
and let them flow into the drains of Houzhidi and Huchi.
He supplied the Dizhu Mountains with water
and dug a tunnel through the Longmen Mountain
to benefit the peoples of the Yan, Dai, Hu, Mo and Xihe.
In the east he irrigated Zhilu,
dammed the wetland of Mengzhu
and divided the water into nine streams
to accumulate the waters of the eastern lands
and to benefit the people of Jizhou.
In the south he regulated the Jiang, Han, Huai and Ru
and let them flow eastward
and pour into the area of the Five Lakes
to benefit the peoples of Chu, Jing, Yue and the Southern Yi.
This tells of the deeds of Yu,
so let us now practice universality.
In former times, when King Wen governed the western territories,
he spread splendor like sun and moon
in the four regions
and in the western territories.

That in the past the sage-kings of the three dynasties - Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, King Wen, and King Wu - became universal kings over the empire and established leadership over the lords of the various states,
These verses show that in antiquity, rulers and lords of the various state could not fail to treat their assistants and subordinates kindly,
by using the analogy of moistening the hand before grasping anything hot
in order to protect the hand from injury. [Adaption of Knoblock, TWH]
In those who give high rank but not the emolument that should go with it
people have no confidence. [Adaption of word order, TWH]
If this is so, then the rich and ement who were rewarded for being worthy,
who were they? [TWH]
Therefore our argument in favor of exalting the worthy
must be investigated regarding this. [Adapted translation: TWH]
He did not demean the small countries for the sake of the big countries,
nor the solitary for the sake of the majority.
Neither did he steal millet and livestock from the peasants to demonstrate [his] power.
Heaven looked down on the kindness of King Wen,
therefore the old and childless
had the opportunity to live their lives up to an old age;
those who were alone and without brothers
had the opportunity to spread themselves among the people;
those who had lost their parents at a young age
had the opportunity to receive support and grow up.
This tells of the deeds of King Wen,
so let us now practice universality!
Once when King Wu was about to perform his service at Mount Tai
and tunnel it,
according to the tradition, he said the following:
Mount Tai has a way.
The king of Zhou, who looks back upon a long line of ancestors, has a task.
The big task will soon be done,
the humane man must act
to save the Shang, Xia, Man, Yi and the despicable Mo.
Although there are relatives of Zhou,
they are not like the humane man.
If there is guilt in the ten thousand regions,
then I alone bear it.
This tells of the deeds of Kind Wu,
let us now practice universality!
For this reason, Master Mo says:
If now the world's gentlemen
faithfully and honestly desire the world to prosper
and abhor it to remain poor;
if they want the world to be well-ordered
and abhor it to remain disordered,
then they should be universal, mutually caring
and exchange mutual benefits.
This is the law of the sage kings
and the way to order the world.
One must strive to practice it.
Master Mo says:
As for the tasks of the humane man,
he must strive to increase the benefit for the world
and to avert harm from it.
Since this is the case,
what are therefore the biggest harms to the world today?
I say:
If the big countries attack the small countries,
the big households bring the small households into disorder,
the strong subjugate the weak,
the majority oppresses the minority,
the cunning scheme against the stupid,
the noble disrespect the mean,
then these are (great) harms to the world.
Moreover, if those who act as rulers over people are not benevolent,
subjects are not loyal,
fathers show no parental care,
sons show no filial piety,
then these too are (great) damages to the world.
Furthermore, if people disregard the lives of others
and use weapons, poison, water or fire
to harm and murder each other,
then these are also great harms to the world.
Let us try to get to the bottom of what the different types of harm arise from.
What is it that they arise from?
Do these arise from sparing and benefitting others?
One must say that this is by no means the case.
Rather, one must say that these arise from harming and murdering others.
If you assign names to those in the world who harm and murder others,
are they those who practice universal
or partial [sparing]?
One must say that they are those who practice partial [sparing].
Since this is the case, is not this exchange of partiality
therefore that from which the greatest harm to the world arises?
For this reason, Master Mo says:
Partiality is to be condemned!
He who condemns others
must have something to change their minds.
If you condemn others but have nothing to change their minds,
it is like fighting water with water,
that is to say, there will be nothing you can do against them.
For this reason, Master Mo says:
Universality is that by which one changes partiality.
Since this is the case, what is the reason why universality can change partiality?
I say:
If you treat another's country like you treat your own,
who would then mobilize his country to attack another's country?
One treats others as one treats oneself.
If you treat the capital city of others like you treat your own,
who would then mobilize his capital city to attack that of another?
One treats others as one treats oneself.
If you treat the household of others like you treat your own,
who would then mobilize his household to bring that of another into disorder?
One treats others as one treats oneself.
If this is the case then, and countries and capital cities do not attack each other
and people's households do not disorder or murder each other,
is this a harm to the world?
Or is it a benefit for the world?
One must say that it is a benefit for the world.
Let us try to get to the bottom of what the different types of benefit arise from.
What is it that they arise from?
Do these arise from harming and murdering others?
One must say that this is by no means the case.
Rather, one must say that these arise from sparing and benefitting others.
If you assign names to those in the world who spare and benefit others,
are they those who practice partial
or universal [sparing]?
One must say that they are those who practice universal [sparing].
Since this is the case, is not this exchange of universality
therefore that from which the greatest benefit for the world arises?
For this reason, Master Mo says:
Universality is to be commended!
Moreover, I said just before:
"As for the tasks of the humane man,
he must strive to increase the benefit for the world
and to avert harm from it."
Now we have found out that universality is that from which great benefit for the world arises,
and that partiality is that from which great harm to the world arises.
For this reason, Master Mo says:
The fact that partiality is to be condemned and universality commended
follows from this principle.
If we now strive for the correct way to increase the benefit of the world and then adopt it,
we take universality as our norm.
Because of this, those with clear-hearing ears and clear-sighted eyes will see and hear for each other.
Because of this, those with agile and powerful arms and legs will act for each other,
and those who have obtained the Way will assiduously teach and instruct others.
Because of this, those who are old and without wife or son
would have someone to look well after them to lead their lives to their end.
Those who are young, weak, orphaned and without father or mother
would have someone to support them so that they can grow up.
Now if we take universality as our norm,
then those would be its benefits.
I do not know for what reason the gentlemen in the world all condemn universality when they hear of it.

However, the arguments of the gentlemen in the world who condemn universality
They say:
If there was universality, that would be good.
Although this may be the case,
how could it be put into practice?
Master Mo says:
If it could not be put into practice,
even I would condemn it as well.
But how could there be something that is good but cannot be put into practice?
Let us try to advance [this issue] from both sides.
Suppose there were two gentlemen.
Let us suppose that one of these gentlemen adheres to partiality
and the other to impartiality.
Accordingly, the argument of the gentleman adhering to partiality would be as follows:
How could I treat my friend's body like I treat my own,
or my friend's parents like I treat my own?
So, if he takes a step back and sees that his friend
is hungry, he would not feed him.
If he was cold, he would not clothe him;
If he was sick, he would not look after him;
If he died, he would not bury him.
Such would be the words of the gentleman who adheres to partiality,
and such would be his actions.
The words of the gentleman who adheres to impartiality would not be such,
nor would his actions.
He would explain:
I have learned that those who are true gentlemen of high standing in the world
must treat their friend's body as they treat their own,
and treat their friend's parents as they treat their own.
Only then can they be true gentlemen of high standing in the world.
So, if he takes a step back and sees that his friend
is hungry, he would feed him.
If he was cold, he would clothe him;
If he was sick, he would look after him;
If he died, he would bury him.
Such would be the words of the gentleman who adheres to impartiality,
and such would be his actions.
Do these two gentlemen
not condemn each other in their words and do they not oppose each other in their actions?
If we assume that these two gentlemen
are certainly faithful in their words
and certainly determined in their actions,
and if we assume that their words and actions match perfectly
like two pieces of a tally,
then there is nothing that is said but not put into action.
If this is the case, then let us venture to ask [the following]: if now on an open plain or wide field
there is someone in armour and helmet
who is about to go into battle,
but his fate, whether he will live or die, is not predictable.
Or there is a dignitary who is sent on an official mission to remote places like Ba, Yue, Qi, or Jing,
but whether he arrives there and returns
is not predictable.
If this is the case, we venture ask: Whom of the following would he choose?
Would he entrust the support of his parents
and the fostering of his wife, sons and household
to a friend who would treat them with impartiality?
Or to a friend who would treat them with partiality?
I am convinced that under these circumstances
there are no foolish men and foolish women in this world.
Even if they happen to be people who condemn impartiality,
they will certainly entrust them to their friend, who will treat them with impartiality.
This means condemning impartiality in one's words,
but preferring impartiality in one's choices,
and so this is a contradiction between words and actions.
I do not know for what reason the gentlemen in the world
all condemn universality when they hear of it.
However, the arguments of the gentlemen in the world who condemn universality do not end here.
They say:
Could it be that you can choose gentlemen,
but not rulers by means of it?
Let us try to advance [this issue] from both sides.
Suppose there were two rulers.
Let us suppose that one of these rulers adheres to impartiality
and the other to partiality.
Accordingly, the argument of the ruler adhering to partiality would be as follows:
How could I treat the bodies of my people like I treat my own?
This is entirely contrary to common sense.
The short duration of a person's life on earth
is comparable to the brevity of the moment when a horse can be seen galloping past through a crack in a wall.
So, if he takes a step back and sees that his people
are hungry, he would not feed them.
If they were cold, he would not clothe them;
if they were sick, he would not look after them;
if they died, he would not bury them.
Such would be the words of the ruler who adheres to partiality,
and such would be his actions.
The words of the ruler who adheres to impartiality would not be such,
nor would his actions.
He would explain:
I have learned that those who are true enlightened rulers in the world
must give precedence to the bodies of the common people
and put their own bodies last.
Only then can they be true enlightened rulers in the world.
So, if he takes a step back and sees that his people
are hungry, he would feed them.
If they were cold, he would clothe them;
if they were sick, he would look after them;
if they died, he would bury them.
Such would be the words of the ruler who adheres to impartiality,
and such would be his actions.
If this is the case and we compare these two rulers,
do they not condemn each other in their words and oppose each other in their actions?
If we assume that these two rulers
are certainly faithful in their words
and certainly determined in their actions,
and if we assume that their words and actions match perfectly
like two pieces of a tally,
then there is nothing that is said but not put into action.
If this is the case, then let us venture to ask [the following]: If now the year has seen the plague
and among the common people there are many who suffer misery, cold and hunger,
and those who are rolled into the ditches and gullies after their death
are already many.
I wonder, if they were to choose one of these two rulers,
whom would they follow?
I am convinced that under these circumstances
there are no foolish men and foolish women in this world.
Even if they happen to be people who condemn impartiality,
they will certainly follow the ruler who adheres to impartiality.
This means condemning impartiality in one's words,
but preferring impartiality in one's choices,
and so this is a contradiction between words and actions.
I do not know for what reason everybody in the world condemns impartiality when he hears of it.
However, the arguments of the gentlemen in the world who condemn universality do not end here.
They say:
Impartiality may be benevolent
and righteous.
This may be so,
but how could it possibly be put into practice?
One can compare the impracticability of impartiality
with lifting up and taking along Mount Tai and crossing a river with it.
Therefore, as far as impartiality is concerned,
one can only hope for it,
but how could it be something that can be put into practice?
Master Mo says:
As for lifting up and taking along Mount Tai and crossing a river with it,
from ancient times to the present day,
since the creation of mankind it never has been accomplished.
Now, as far as the impartial, attentive sparing of one another and the exchange of mutual benefits are concerned,
the former sages and true great kings put them into practice personally.
How do we know that the former sages and true great kings put them into practice personally?
Master Mo says:
I am not their contemporary,
neither have I personally heard their voices
or seen their faces.
We know it through what they have written on bamboo and silk,
carved in metal and stone,
engraved in basins and vessels,
which have been handed down to posterity and their descendants.
The "Great Oath" says:
"King Wen spread splendor like sun and moon
in the four regions
and in the western territories."
This means, then, that the vastness with which King Wen attentively spared the world
is comparable to the absence of partiality with which the sun and moon impartially illuminate the world.
This, then, is the impartiality of King Wen.
Even what Master Mo calls impartiality
takes its model from King Wen.
Moreover, this is not only true for the "Great Oath",
but even for the "Oath of Yu".
Yu said:
"You numerous multitudes,
hear my words!
It is not that I alone, the little child, dare to rise in revolt.
Foolish are these Miao,
they deserve Heaven's punishment.
As for me, I will lead you, the feudal lords of the various states,
to wage war against the Miao."

Moreover, this is not only true for the "Oath of Yu",

Tang said:
Only I, the little child Lü,
dare to sacrifice a dark bull
to report to Heaven on high and Sovereign Earth:
"Now there is a great drought,
and so I, Lü, take responsibility for it.
I am not sure whether I committed a crime against Heaven or Earth.
Those who have done good, I did not dare to hide.
Those who are guilty, I did not dare pardon.
The choice lay with the Lord's heart.
If there is guilt in the ten thousand regions,
I take responsibility for it.
If I prove myself guilty of a crime,
it shall not affect the ten thousand regions."
So this is to say that Tang, honored with the position of the Son of Heaven
and the wealth to rule the world,
did nevertheless not shy away from sacrificing himself
to appease the gods and spirits.
This, then, is the impartiality of Tang.
Even what Master Mo calls impartiality
takes its model from Tang.
Moreover, this is not only true for the "Oath of Yu" and the "Oath of Tang",
but even for the Odes of Zhou.
In the "Odes of Zhou" it says:
"Broad and extensive is the emperor's way,
neither partial nor partisan.
Even and fair is the emperor's way,
neither partisan nor partial.
It is straight like an arrow
and flat like a whetstone.
The gentleman walks on it,
the ordinary man approaches it."
Do not these our words mean the Way?
In ancient times, when Wen and Wu administered the government,
they divided equally, rewarded the virtuous, punished the violent,
and did not show favouritism towards their relatives or brothers.
This, then, is the impartiality of Wen and Wu.
Even what Master Mo calls impartiality
takes its model from Wen and Wu.
I do not know for what reason everybody in the world condemns impartiality when he hears of it.
